name: Katharine Elizabeth O'Brien
content:
Katharine Elizabeth O'Brien (1901 – 1986) was an American mathematician, musician and poet.
 Born in Amesbury, Massachusetts to parents who had emigrated from Ireland, O'Brien's family moved to Maine while at the age of three.[1]  She was class valedictorian when she graduated from Deering High School in Portland, Maine in 1917.  She then attended nearby Bates College from which she graduated in 1922 with honors in both mathematics and science.  Despite her science-focused majors, she also was drawn to and pursued both poetry and music.[2]
 O'Brien continued to take courses in mathematics, at Smith College, from 1922 to 1923. In 1924, she earned a master's degree in mathematics at Cornell with a major focus in geometry and a minor in analysis.
She taught mathematics briefly in 1925, at Jordan High School in Lewiston, Maine.
She joined the faculty at the College of New Rochelle as an English teacher, but soon moved to mathematics.[2]
She became the chair of the mathematics department, and remained there for 11 years.[3][4]
 Beginning in 1936, she studied for a doctorate at Brown University, completing her Ph.D. in mathematical analysis in 1939.[2]
At Brown, she worked with Jacob Tamarkin as her advisor; her dissertation was Some Problems in Interpolation by Characteristic Functions of Linear Differential Systems of the Fourth Order.[5]
 In 1940, O'Brien joined the faculty at Deering High School in Portland, Maine, and she taught there until her retirement in 1971.[2]
 O'Brien was the author of Sequences (Houghton-Mifflin Mathematics Enrichment Series, 1966).
Some of her poetry was collected in the book Excavation and Other Verse (Anthoensen Press, 1967).[6]
 The University of Maine gave O'Brien an honorary doctorate in 1960,[3] and Bowdoin College gave her another in 1965.[3][4]
 O'Brien won the Deborah Morton Award, an annual award for Maine women of distinction, in 1985.[3][7]
 She also became a fellow of the International Academy of Poetry and, in 1967, an elected member of the New York Academy of Sciences.[3]
raw:
American mathematician, musician and poet
Katharine Elizabeth O'Brien (1901 – 1986) was an American mathematician, musician and poet.

Contents

1 Early life
2 Higher education and career
3 Books
4 Recognition
5 References
6 External links


Early life[edit]
Born in Amesbury, Massachusetts to parents who had emigrated from Ireland, O'Brien's family moved to Maine while at the age of three.[1]  She was class valedictorian when she graduated from Deering High School in Portland, Maine in 1917.  She then attended nearby Bates College from which she graduated in 1922 with honors in both mathematics and science.  Despite her science-focused majors, she also was drawn to and pursued both poetry and music.[2]

Higher education and career[edit]
O'Brien continued to take courses in mathematics, at Smith College, from 1922 to 1923. In 1924, she earned a master's degree in mathematics at Cornell with a major focus in geometry and a minor in analysis.
She taught mathematics briefly in 1925, at Jordan High School in Lewiston, Maine.
She joined the faculty at the College of New Rochelle as an English teacher, but soon moved to mathematics.[2]
She became the chair of the mathematics department, and remained there for 11 years.[3][4]
Beginning in 1936, she studied for a doctorate at Brown University, completing her Ph.D. in mathematical analysis in 1939.[2]
At Brown, she worked with Jacob Tamarkin as her advisor; her dissertation was Some Problems in Interpolation by Characteristic Functions of Linear Differential Systems of the Fourth Order.[5]
In 1940, O'Brien joined the faculty at Deering High School in Portland, Maine, and she taught there until her retirement in 1971.[2]

Books[edit]
O'Brien was the author of Sequences (Houghton-Mifflin Mathematics Enrichment Series, 1966).
Some of her poetry was collected in the book Excavation and Other Verse (Anthoensen Press, 1967).[6]

Recognition[edit]
The University of Maine gave O'Brien an honorary doctorate in 1960,[3] and Bowdoin College gave her another in 1965.[3][4]
O'Brien won the Deborah Morton Award, an annual award for Maine women of distinction, in 1985.[3][7]
She also became a fellow of the International Academy of Poetry and, in 1967, an elected member of the New York Academy of Sciences.[3]

References[edit]


^ "Katharine O'Brien Papers, 1905-1986 | Maine Women Writers Collection | University of New England in Maine, Tangier and Online". Une.edu. Retrieved 2018-12-12.

^ a b c d Judy Green; Jeanne LaDuke. "SUPPLEMENTARY MATERIAL FOR PIONEERING WOMEN IN AMERICAN MATHEMATICS : THE PRE-1940 PHD'S" (PDF). Ams.org. Retrieved 13 December 2018.

^ a b c d e "Obituaries", Bates College Alumni Magazine, Fall 1998

^ a b Katharine Elizabeth O'Brien, mathematician, teacher, and poet (PDF), Bowdoin College, 1965

^ Katharine Elizabeth O'Brien at the Mathematics Genealogy Project

^ Alexanderson, Gerald L. (2015), "Twelve classics people who love mathematics should know; or, 'What do you mean, you haven't read E. T. Bell?'",  in Kennedy, Stephen F.; Albers, Donald J.; Alexanderson, Gerald L.; Dumbaugh, Della; Farris, Frank A.; Haunsperger, Deanna B.; Zorn, Paul (eds.), A Century of Advancing Mathematics, Mathematical Association of America, Washington, DC, pp. 351–364, ISBN 978-0-88385-588-1, MR 3381845

^ Award recipients, The Deborah Morton Society, retrieved 2019-01-26


External links[edit]
Maine Women's Writer's Cooperative offers information about O'Brien's life and her collected papers
Blogsite at the University of New England contains three of her math-linked poems.
